instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message:
Liquid Damage

Had a main line short wouldnt boot. Removed short and it boots.
Flashing Folder
Checked <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> found a short on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL>
Replaced <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> short gone
I get 0v on L9340 and L9330
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> is 3.311v
<SIGNAL>STORAGE_LB_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>STORAGE_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 0v (when a line says EN L does that mean it goes low for reset or stays low?) I feel this is my issue
<SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_L</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>SSD_PCIE_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v

Trying to find the root of where its all turned on. Seems that comes from CPU and Im missing but Im not sure if that circuit has a prior trigger or source that tells CPU to enable SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message:
Check J9600 for corrosion; clean it and try again.

"<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 0"
Correct, as is active low; what "_L" means...

"<SIGNAL>SSD_PCIE_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v"
For same reason, this should be 0V; or PCH will not provide clock to SSD.

But you still miss 1V8 and 1V2 for SSD.
Check if <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 0v but if I disconnect the Life Boat Connector the voltage on the feed side is only 0.6v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message:
You must check all voltages with SSD/Lifeboat connected.
Also check diode mode to ground in both cases.
Be sure no corrosion there and good solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message: J9600 was clean. No corrosion on that connector. Ill check both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message:
Did you pick <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> from same donor board?
It may have firmware...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message: <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> was a new chip from RossmannRepair. Dont have a donor board for this model currently. Diode readings will be a guess if they are ok or not. Obvious OL or 0 will be questionable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flashing Folder
threads.message: Customer doesnt want to wait so I guess Ill have to give up here on it. Sucks because its so close to working.
